Pennsylvanians Won Test 6-0 Last
Year in Hard Fought Battle;
Same Team Back
DEFENSE GOOD, VAN ORMAN
Despite Score Hopkins Did Well
in Penn Game Last Week
Says Head Coach
In an effort to efface the 6-0 defeat of last year, Johns Hopkins
,will meet Haverford College in the
first home game of the season at
Homewood tomorrow.
Although the Pennsylvanians
have not played yet this year and
are therefore an unknown quantity,
the Blue Jays will take the field as
.favorites. This is largely as a result of the showing made against
Penn last week. Although the Jay
team took a terrific battering from
Lou Young's well-balanced' eleven,
their condition was so good that
there was not one serious injury.
Van Orman's charges showed
that -in all departments, plunging,
running, kicking and passing, they
are well drilled and dangerous.
Bobby Lyons, the new Hopkins
triple threat man, showed up well,
his kicks being well placed and his
running and passing heady.
Van Orman Pleased

Coach Van Orman said today, "I
would not like to shy who will win.
Haverford hasn't played yet and so
is an unknown quantity. I am very
well satisfied. with the showing
against Penn. Our defense is good
but it remains to be seen how well
the attack will work. Our line is
not as strong as last year."
As to weight Haverford is heavier than the Jay team by five and a
half pounds. The backfield tips the
beam down four pounds more per
man than Hopkins and the line avefages three pounds more. FrOm
tackle to tackle, however,'the Blue
team is heavier.
The Jay team, though light, is
unusually fast and has strong ends.
Mallonee is possibly one of the best
wing men in Hopkins history and
Kaufholz has been working well.
In the backfield Pindell, whose
line plunging was a feature of last
year's Maryland game, will be hitting the line again. Lyons suffered
a slight injury in practice Wednesday, but this is not expected to interfere with his game tomorrow.
Lawrence and Boyton are in good
condition and both should play a
hard game. The line, from tackle
to tackle has, but two experienced
men, Leibensperger and Biddison
Kaufman, though a junior, is a
newcomer to college football. Clayton played fullback last year but
has never before played in the line.
Dill is a freshman. Haverford has'
the powerful Middleton-Webster
backfield of last year back again.
Although they have had only two
weeks of practice, the Philadelphians are said to be in good trim.
Robert Middleton, captain, and former Hopkins man, will lead the
team on the field.

THE REAL TEST

Tomorrow afternoon the 1926 football team will trot out
on Homewood Field to take on Haverford in the first home
game of the season. We know that we are giving out a bit
of stale news; everybody knows about the game, but that is not
the point. The real question is "What are we going to do
about it?"
For over a month the squad has been working daily, anc:
it looks already as if the results are the same as they have been
in the past. Handicapped as usual with limited material, Coach
Van Orman and his assistants are building up another of the
teams with the well known Hopkins fight, equal to any team in
their class, and ready to give much stronger opponents a run
for their money.
Haverford is almost an ideal opponent for the Jay eleven
to tackle at this time. The two are evenly matched. The Pennsylvanians always come down with a 'scrappy team and a large
crowd of followers, for Haverford would rather beat Hopkins
in football than have ice cream for dinner every day for a year.
In fact, there is nothing they enjoy more, as those of us who
saw their 6-0 victory last fall can testify. That defeat of las;t
year is the last straw—we've got to beat Haverford.
As we said just a Minute ago, the squad has worked hard.
nearly everybody knows what that means, and those that
don't ought to go out to the field a few afternoons and see.
Over two hours routine signal practice, back breaking exercises, or hard scrimmage every day. Squad, coaches, and managers are putting everything they have into building a team
that will be a credit to Hopkins.
As for the rest of the students, the "men in the street"
as far as college football is concerned, the least they can do is
back the team to the limit, in every way possible. The best
ways and the easiest are attendance at games, and good yelling while there. In this, the freshmen, on account of their numbers, play a large part.
Freshman yell practice was poor the first two days of this
week there are a lot of slackers in the ranks. Also, it wouldn't
be a bad idea for upperclassmen to help out.
The spirit shown this week has been poor, but it can be
improved in the future and very little harm will be done.
The real test comes tomorrow.
The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of
Norman B. Gardiner, Jr., '28,'and H. Addison Campbell, '29,
from the Editorial and Business Staffs, respectively.

DORM
DOINGS
This year the campus domicile
is just a little overcrowded. Several rooms have been subdivided
to permit more students to be accommodated. Likewise things are
congested in the dining room.
Many residents are fast learning
to eat with their elbows in their
laps. This relieves matters considerably.

it is with pain that we notice a
flock of summer growth mustaches upon some of the former
residents. These additions have
been the reason for many of their
bearers not being recognized by
old friends.
*

A number of foreign s- tudents
are again at the dormitory, The
Page School of International Law
is thought to bring many of them
to Homewood. Some few are nutable to speak English. However,
they make their wants known
through fellow-countrymen.

Pennsylvanians Won Test 6-0 Last
Year in Hard Fought Battle;
Same Team Back
DEFENSE GOOD, VAN ORMAN
Despite Score Hopkins Did Well
in Penn Game Last Week
Says Head Coach
In an effort to efface the 6-0 defeat of last year, Johns Hopkins
,will meet Haverford College in the
first home game of the season at
Homewood tomorrow.
Although the Pennsylvanians
have not played yet this year and
are therefore an unknown quantity,
the Blue Jays will take the field as
.favorites. This is largely as a result of the showing made against
Penn last week. Although the Jay
team took a terrific battering from
Lou Young's well-balanced' eleven,
their condition was so good that
there was not one serious injury.
Van Orman's charges showed
that -in all departments, plunging,
running, kicking and passing, they
are well drilled and dangerous.
Bobby Lyons, the new Hopkins
triple threat man, showed up well,
his kicks being well placed and his
running and passing heady.
Van Orman Pleased

Coach Van Orman said today, "I
would not like to shy who will win.
Haverford hasn't played yet and so
is an unknown quantity. I am very
well satisfied. with the showing
against Penn. Our defense is good
but it remains to be seen how well
the attack will work. Our line is
not as strong as last year."
As to weight Haverford is heavier than the Jay team by five and a
half pounds. The backfield tips the
beam down four pounds more per
man than Hopkins and the line avefages three pounds more. FrOm
tackle to tackle, however,'the Blue
team is heavier.
The Jay team, though light, is
unusually fast and has strong ends.
Mallonee is possibly one of the best
wing men in Hopkins history and
Kaufholz has been working well.
In the backfield Pindell, whose
line plunging was a feature of last
year's Maryland game, will be hitting the line again. Lyons suffered
a slight injury in practice Wednesday, but this is not expected to interfere with his game tomorrow.
Lawrence and Boyton are in good
condition and both should play a
hard game. The line, from tackle
to tackle has, but two experienced
men, Leibensperger and Biddison
Kaufman, though a junior, is a
newcomer to college football. Clayton played fullback last year but
has never before played in the line.
Dill is a freshman. Haverford has'
the powerful Middleton-Webster
backfield of last year back again.
Although they have had only two
weeks of practice, the Philadelphians are said to be in good trim.
Robert Middleton, captain, and former Hopkins man, will lead the
team on the field.

THE REAL TEST

Tomorrow afternoon the 1926 football team will trot out
on Homewood Field to take on Haverford in the first home
game of the season. We know that we are giving out a bit
of stale news; everybody knows about the game, but that is not
the point. The real question is "What are we going to do
about it?"
For over a month the squad has been working daily, anc:
it looks already as if the results are the same as they have been
in the past. Handicapped as usual with limited material, Coach
Van Orman and his assistants are building up another of the
teams with the well known Hopkins fight, equal to any team in
their class, and ready to give much stronger opponents a run
for their money.
Haverford is almost an ideal opponent for the Jay eleven
to tackle at this time. The two are evenly matched. The Pennsylvanians always come down with a 'scrappy team and a large
crowd of followers, for Haverford would rather beat Hopkins
in football than have ice cream for dinner every day for a year.
In fact, there is nothing they enjoy more, as those of us who
saw their 6-0 victory last fall can testify. That defeat of las;t
year is the last straw—we've got to beat Haverford.
As we said just a Minute ago, the squad has worked hard.
nearly everybody knows what that means, and those that
don't ought to go out to the field a few afternoons and see.
Over two hours routine signal practice, back breaking exercises, or hard scrimmage every day. Squad, coaches, and managers are putting everything they have into building a team
that will be a credit to Hopkins.
As for the rest of the students, the "men in the street"
as far as college football is concerned, the least they can do is
back the team to the limit, in every way possible. The best
ways and the easiest are attendance at games, and good yelling while there. In this, the freshmen, on account of their numbers, play a large part.
Freshman yell practice was poor the first two days of this
week there are a lot of slackers in the ranks. Also, it wouldn't
be a bad idea for upperclassmen to help out.
The spirit shown this week has been poor, but it can be
improved in the future and very little harm will be done.
The real test comes tomorrow.
The NEWS-LETTER regrets to announce the resignation of
Norman B. Gardiner, Jr., '28,'and H. Addison Campbell, '29,
from the Editorial and Business Staffs, respectively.

This year the campus domicile
is just a little overcrowded. Several rooms have been subdivided
to permit more students to be accommodated. Likewise things are
congested in the dining room.
Many residents are fast learning
to eat with their elbows in their
laps. This relieves matters considerably.

it is with pain that we notice a
flock of summer growth mustaches upon some of the former
residents. These additions have
been the reason for many of their
bearers not being recognized by
old friends.

are again at the dormitory, The
Page School of International Law
is thought to bring many of them
to Homewood. Some few are nutable to speak English. However,
they make their wants known
through fellow-countrymen.
